metadata.title: Formulation and application of a new generation of lipid nano-carriers for the food bioactive ingredients

Review
Formulation and application of a new generation of lipid nano-carriers for the food bioactive ingredients
Iman Katouzian a, Afshin Faridi Esfanjani b, Seid Mahdi Jafari c, *, Sahar Akhavan c
a Young Researchers and Elites Club, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran b Young Researchers and Elites Club, Tabriz Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tabriz, Iran c Department of Food Materials and Process Design Engineering, Gorgan University of Agricultural Science and Natural Resources, Gorgan, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 8 December 2016 Received in revised form 23 June 2017 Accepted 24 July 2017 Available online 25 July 2017
Keywords: Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) Nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) Food industry Delivery systems Formulation
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: smjafari@gau.ac.ir (S.M. Jafari).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tifs.2017.07.017 0924-2244/© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Background: Lipid nanoparticles are innovative delivery systems, which are similar to the prevalently used emulsions, with the differences in size and structure in which the water-insoluble core is dispersed in a combination of solid and liquid lipids stabilized by surfactants. Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) plus nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) are novel and promising nano-vehicles, which are of great interest to be applied in the food sector owing to their exclusive properties, as investigated in this revision. Scope and approach: LNs and NLCs are produced to unite the advantages of structures like liposomes and emulsions and they can be formulated to achieve desirable protection and release of food bioactive ingredients. This review highlights the pros and cons of using SLNs and NLCs in the food industry. Furthermore, the commonly applied production methods and formulations along with the recently conducted studies in the field of food science and technology are underlined. Key findings and conclusions: These nano-vehicles have the potential to be employed in the food industrial applications in regard to their beneficial properties like simple production technology, low cost and scale up ability. These nanocarriers have been mostly applied in the pharmaceutical industries and are recently being utilized in the food sector, which seems to have great impacts on this industry as well as their commercialization in the near future.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Today, the benefits of nanotechnology has influenced many branches in the food sector such as, packaging, bioactives compound delivery systems, and designing optimized formulations with the aim of increased bioavailability (Gibbs et al., 1999). Nanoencapsulation of food ingredients via various nanocarriers may elevate the stability and viability of bioactives as well as other applications to improve the quality of food products. The nanoencapsulation bodies can be carbohydrate, protein or lipid based. Carbohydrate and protein networks are not suitable for industrial purposes because of the execution of intricate chemical or heat processing, which cannot be entirely controlled (Fathi, Mozafari, & Mohebbi, 2012). On the other hand, lipid-based nanoparticles bear the advantages of (Fathi et al., 2012; Mohammadi, Jafari, Esfanjani, & Akhavan, 2016a):
biocompatibility more encapsulation efficiency targeted effect modified release low toxicity lack of organic solvent for the formulation ease of continuous production
That is why recent investigations are focused on lipid-based carriers to be applied in pharmaceutical and food sectors. Lipidbased nanocarriers in the food industry encompass nanospheres, nanoliposomes, nanoemulsions and lipid nanoparticles with solid/ liquid networks including Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) and Nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) (Fang, Fang, Liu, & Su, 2008).
Most of the bioactives and nutrients; such as polyphenols, carotenoids, lipophilic vitamins, phytosterols, etc. are naturally hydrophobic. In addition, the absorption of bioactives is facilitated in the small intestine if it is accompanied with an edible lipid due to the amplification in the content of mixed micelles responsible for the solubilization and transportation of lipophilic agents (Porter,
Trevaskis, & Charman, 2007; Pouton, 2006). In comparison to other lipid-based nanocarriers, such as nanoliposomes and nanoemulsions, SLNs and NLCs have lately attracted much attention from the food and pharmaceutical industries due to their advantages. A schematic representation of these carriers is shown in Fig. 1.
However, the benefits of using NLCs and SLNs are not completely proved yet and there are several unanswered questions concerning this topic. For instance, do the release kinetics and profile differ between SLNs and NLCs? Does different guestmolecule loading affect the release profile in SLNs and NLCs? How is the stability of NLCs at various storage conditions compared to SLNs? How does the administration route affect the release profile in both nanovehicles (Kovacevic, Savic, Vuleta, Müller, & Keck, 2011)? Therefore, further studies should be designed and executed to answer these questions and elucidate the future applications of these nanocarriers in the food sector (Das, Ng, & Tan, 2012).
In this review paper, the latest progress made in the nanoencapsulation of nutrients within the SLNs and NLCs networks are discussed. Also, the production techniques, physicochemical features, release profiles and modeling plus their functions within the food systems are explored. Finally, recent studies and applications of SLNs and NLCs in the field of food and nutraceutical industries are provided.

sections.heading: 2. Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs)
sections.text:
Among the mentioned lipid nanoparticles, SLNs contain lipid droplets that are fully crystallized and have an organized crystalline structure with the bioactive components accommodated within the lipid matrix (Weiss et al., 2008). The advent of SLNs dates back to 1990 when these nano-structures were manufactured by replacing the liquid state lipid (oil) with the solid one in the emulsion and thus the lipids are solid at ambient temperature as well as the body temperature (Müller, Radtke, &Wissing, 2002a,b). SLNs are novel nanoparticulate vehicles developed to overcome the drawbacks of other nano lipid-based carriers, such as nanoliposomes, nanoemulsions, etc. According to (Mu Eller, Ma Eder, & Gohla, 2000), SLNs are able to prolong the release period according to their solid state, protecting the active agents against unwanted chemical reactions like oxidation. Some of the advantages of the employment of SLNs as efficient nanovehicles are listed below (Madureira et al., 2015; Mozafari, 2006; Sagalowicz & Leser, 2010).
High entrapment efficiency Organic solvents are not used in the production methods Being low-cost and simple so as to make it possible for largescale manufacturing Able to protect the core bioactive compounds (both lipophilic and hydrophilic) against external harsh conditions Providing a flexible release profile via their solid matrix Prolonged release due to slow disintegration Can be utilized in both liquid and solid state food products No biotoxicity is considered for these carriers as they are made from naturally occurring food components.
However, like other nanocarriers, SLNs also have their own disadvantages which are (Aditya & Ko, 2015; Weiss et al., 2008):
Possible gelation phenomenon Unexpected transitions in fat crystalline structures leading to the expulsion of core materials during storage Assembly and growth of particles Low capacity for the incorporation of bioactives within the nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Structure of SLNs
sections.text:
SLNs are formulated from one solid lipid or a blend of solid lipids. In general, the mobility of bioactive components can be controlled by altering the physical state of the lipid matrix within the SLNs (Müller et al., 2002a,b). The bioactive substance has a much lower diffusion rate within these applicable nanovehicles hence prolonged release occurs. According to Üner (2006), the dispersion of the bioactive compounds inside the SLNs is classified into three types (Fig. 2) known as solid solution model, bioactive enriched shell and bioactive enriched core.
In the first model, the bioactive ingredients are dispersed throughout the lipid matrix; in addition, no surface active agent and surfactant are used for the fabrication of this type. Considering the bioactive-enriched shell type, the bioactive ingredients are transferred to the water phase because of partitioning during the hot homogenization preparation. The partitioning rate scales directly with the solubility of the bioactive ingredient in the water phase as well as increase in temperature. After the cooling process, the solubility of the bioactive ingredient in the water phase decreases gradually and re-partitioning occurs in a way that the bioactive compounds are transferred to the lipid phase owing to their decreased solubility in water. Ultimately, the bioactive compounds are located in the external shell/surface of the SLNs. The third and last type is the bioactive-enriched core model in which the bioactive ingredient is dissolved in the molten lipid nearly to its saturation level. Afterwards, the cooling process of the mixture results in the supersaturation of the bioactive ingredient in the molten lipid and its precipitation before the recrystallization of lipids. In this mode of entrapment, the level of the SLN related bioactive ingredient is associated with the nature and concentration of the surfactant encircling the SLN's core.

sections.heading: 2.2. Application of SLNs in the food industry
sections.text:
SLNs, as the modern type of nano lipid carriers have found their way in different fields. Because of their remarkable stability and high loading capacity, they are widely applied in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic fields. Nevertheless, reports about their application in functional food industries were greatly limited concerning the following considerations (Jaiswal, Gidwani, & Vyas, 2016):
✓ SLNs are particularly suitable for encapsulating and delivery of lipophilic bioactive compounds, such as flavors, biocidal compounds and drugs into aqueous-based foods. Yet, incorporating hydrophilic bioactives in lipid nanoparticles is difficult due to the tendency of partitioning, related to the encapsulated molecules in the water during the production process of nanoparticles (Singh, Dobhal, Jain, Pandit, & Chakraborty, 2010). ✓ SLNs can be formulated on an industrial scale but GRAS or foodgrade ingredients are required. Since many substances that are utilized in the pharmaceutical industries are not allowed in food in large quantity, further studies are then required for the selection of appropriate materials to be incorporated within the food systems (Tamjidi, Shahedi, Varshosaz, & Nasirpour, 2013). ✓ The ingredients should not have a negative effect on the sensory properties of SLNs-incorporated foods (Du, 2011). ✓ Stability of SLNs must be examined during processing and storage of foods against mechanical and physicochemical stresses, such as pressure, stirring, thermal processing, light, drying, freezing, pH, and environmental storage conditions (Tamjidi et al., 2013). ✓ SLNs should remain solid at room and GI tract temperatures. The solid lipid, like liquid lipid, can be digested in the body by lipase but its digestion rate is much lower in comparison to the liquid state lipid (McClements & Li, 2010). Moreover, if the bioactive is introduced to the crystalline form inside the lipid nanoparticle, its bioavailability may decrease than that of non-crystalline form.
Nevertheless, the usage of SLNs in the food area has developed greatly. SLNs are practical delivery systems for lipophilic nutraceuticals, which may increase their stability and bioavailability as well as dispersibility in aqueous media e.g. beverages. Hence, as enlisted in Table 1, a broad range of bioactive compounds have been tested and incorporated into these versatile nano-delivery systems for various food applications, such as a-tocopherol in glyceryl behenate (de Carvalho et al., 2013), beta-carotene in 50:50 cocoa butter and hydrogenated palm oil (Qian, Decker, Xiao, & McClements, 2013), resveratrol in stearic acid (Pandita, Kumar, Poonia, & Lather, 2014), rosmarinic acid within carnauba wax (Madureira et al., 2015), curcuminoids in tristearin, trimyristin and glyceryl monostearate (Nayak, Tiyaboonchai, Patankar, Madhusudhan, & Souto, 2010), copaiba oil and allantoin in cetyl palmitate (Svetlichny et al., 2015), Zataria multiflora essential oil within glyceril mono stearate and Precirol® ATO 5 (Nasseri, Golmohammadzadeh, Arouiee, Jaafari, & Neamati, 2016) and
peppermint essential oil loaded in fully hydrogenated soybean oil (Yang& Ciftci, 2016). These investigations reflect the enhanced rate of bioavailability plus the stability of the active compounds being entrapped in SLNs. Furthermore, the encapsulation efficiency, size, stability and other characteristics may be altered as a result of the emulsifier type and amount, nano-lipid vehicle type, environmental factors and temperature.

sections.heading: 3. Nano-structured lipid carriers (NLCs)
sections.text:
NLCs, as another type of lipid-based vehicles entered the nanoencapsulation field lately to cover the deficiencies found in SLNs. The main purpose was to enhance the loading capacity and to inhibit the expulsion of bioactive compounds. These nanovehicles are produced by dispersion of a mixture of solid and liquid lipids plus the bioactive ingredients (as inner phase) in water along with emulsifiers (as outer phase). In contrast to SLNs, the presence of liquid lipid in inner phase of NLCs causes the possibility of entrapping bioactive ingredients, which are better solubilized in liquid lipid. On the other hand, the mixture of lipids in NLCs causes slower polymorphic transition and low crystallinity index. In brief, the composition of inner phase of NLCs can provide higher loading capacity, higher encapsulation efficiency, and higher bioavailability of nano-encapsulated ingredients in comparison to SLNs (Müller et al., 2002a), which were described in the previous section. Hence, this section provides some main information about formulation, structure, and application of NLCs.
Some of the advantages of employing NLCs in the nanoencapsulation of food components are (Fathi et al., 2012; http:// www.pharmasol-berlin.de/lipidnano.php3; Müller et al., 2002a):
More available space for the accommodation of bioactives More loading content Higher solid content (30e50%) may be formed in the suspensions Enhanced dosage of the core material in the produced nanocapsules

sections.heading: 3.1. Structure of NLCs
sections.text:
The structure of NLCs with respect to the aim of nanoencapsulation, makeup, production methods, and type of core materials can be classified in three different morphologies (Müller et al., 2002a), which are imperfect crystal, amorphous and multiple

categories as shown in Fig. 3. In the First model, using different lipids with distinct dimensions may lead to higher distances between the lipids and therefore more guest agents are accommodated among the lipid structures. In order to achieve the best results, solid lipids are mixed with oils (liquid state); this model is known as the imperfect type NLC. In SLNs, the bioactive ingredients are incorporated in limited space due to the perfect crystal lattice of solid lipid matrix and induce the expulsion of the nano-encapsulated ingredient. In contrast, the application of a combination of lipids containing liquid and solid lipid renders an imperfect crystal in NLCs and the bioactive ingredients are incorporated in the amorphous building
blocks. Thus, the barriers of SLNs can be removed by deviation of crystallization. The imperfection rate can be increased by using a mixture of glycerides with variable fatty acid chains that form a solid matrix with fluctuating distances best suited for the accommodation of bioactive compounds (Müller et al., 2002a).
In the second model termed as multiple type NLCs, bioactives which are more soluble in oils than solid lipids are dissolved in oils, therefore they are not decomposed by the solid lipids. To minimize the expulsion of nano-encapsulated ingredients, NLCs can be fabricated by blending solid lipids with certain lipids, such as hydroxyoctacosanylhydroxystearate, isopropyl myristate or MCT. In this manner, the non-crystalline lipid nanoparticles are formed in
which the lipid core congeals in the form of an amorphous body. This is an amorphous type of NLC and can be used for the retardation of release of nano-encapsulated ingredients by maintaining the polymorphicity of the lipid matrix (Müller et al., 2002a).
Lastly, the third group called amorphous type NLCs, does prevent the problem of expulsion induced by the crystallization of solid lipids. Here, crystallization is reduced after cooling by blending particular lipids, such as isopropyl myristate and hydroxyl stearate. In other words, the third type of NLCs namely multiple is an oil in solid lipid in water solution (like the water in oil in water emulsions). These multiple networks are especially applied to the entrapment of ingredients being highly soluble in liquid lipids. Indeed, the liquid lipid nano-compartments contain labile ingredients that are scattered in a solid-state lipid matrix. Hence, the release of a high amount of bioactive compounds inside the liquid lipid nano-compartments may be regulated by the encircling solid lipid barrier. Generally, in the production phase of multiple NLCs, two basic points should be taken into account: selection of appropriate liquid and solid lipid for complete miscibility and mixing a solid lipid with a higher amount of liquid lipid. The liquid lipid nano-compartments are created by phase separation. This occurs during cooling step of production; NLCs contain a high amount of liquid lipids by the hot homogenization method, the solubility of the liquid lipid in the solid lipid matrix is exceeded and the nano-droplet of liquid lipid being incorporated into the solid lipid matrix (Müller et al., 2002a).

sections.heading: 3.2. Application of NLCs in the food industry
sections.text:
NLCs are one of the practical delivery systems not only in food but also in the cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries. The bioavailability, penetration, absorption, protection and release of bioactive ingredients can be optimized by their encapsulation in NLCs. So, NLCs are introduced as fine lipid-based systems for delivery of drugs to different organs of the body and to prepare functional foods. Currently, NLCs are widely employed as practical delivery systems and their final structure depends on the purpose of encapsulation plus the type of the encased ingredient.
Lately, the public interest of healthy foods namely functional has dramatically extended. Functional foods are fortified by bioactive ingredients, such as antioxidant, antimicrobial, antidiseases, essential oils, natural coloring and flavoring agents, etc. (Chen,
Weiss, & Shahidi, 2006). Meanwhile, these bioactive ingredients are prone to degradation by environmental stresses (e.g., pH, light, oxygen, and etc.), expulsion from the vector, rapid excretion from the body and low absorption by intestinal cells. Therefore, the bioactive ingredients are encased by practical vehicles in order to protect them against undesirable factors and produce fortified food products. NLCs, as one of the lipid-based encapsulation vehicles, can be successfully used as a fundamental delivery system for the fortification of foods accommodating a variety of bioavailable ingredients (Fathi et al., 2012).
Up to now,many investigations have been carried out in order to encapsulate nutrients within the NLCs. Some of the recent studies performed in this area are entrapment of alpha-lipoic acid in glycerin monostearate and glyceride (Wang, Tang, Zhou, & Xia, 2014), astaxanthin in glyceryl behenate and oleic acid (Tamjidi, Shahedi, Varshosaz, & Nasirpour, 2014), beta-carotene in palmitic acid and corn oil (Hejri, Khosravi, Gharanjig, & Hejazi, 2013), quercetin in glyceryl monostearate and caprylic capric triglyceride (Ni, Sun, Zhao, & Xia, 2015), green tea extract in glyceryl stearate, cetyl palmitate, grape seed oil and sea buckthorn oil (Manea, Vasile, & Meghea, 2014), rutin in cocoa butter and oleic acid (Babazadeh, Ghanbarzadeh, & Hamishehkar, 2016), mono, di and triterpenes in beeswax together with caprylic/capric triglyceride (Laso n, Sikora, Ogonowski, Tabaszewska, & Skoczylas, 2016), cold pressed fruit and kernel seed oils in paraffin oil, beeswax, glycerol and mono, di and tri acylglycerols (Krasodomska, Paolicelli, Cesa, Casadei, & Jungnickel, 2016), Brucea javanica oil incorporated in glyceryl monostearate, medium-chain triglyceride, stearic acid plus Cremophor EL (Lv et al., 2016), and curcumin accommodation within soybean phospholipids, glyceryl monostearate, medium chain triglyceride and steric acid with the aim of improving oral delivery (Chanburee & Tiyaboonchai, 2016).
More information about the food application of NLCs and some recently pursued investigations in this area are gathered in Table 2.

sections.heading: 4. Formulation of SLNs and NLCs
sections.text:
The SLNs and NLCs as nano-scale delivery systems are basically composed of an inner phase containing lipids (solid or solid and liquid), surface active materials (emulsifiers), and water. These systems are derived from O/W emulsion, with the exception that the inner phase of SLNs contain 100% solid lipid and NLCs contain
30% liquid lipid (oil) and 70% solid lipid. The solid lipids have a melting point above room and body temperature, but the liquid lipid exhibits a melting point much lower than the ambient and body temperature. Besides, the application of suitable emulsifiers is necessarily needed for achieving a fine dispersion of these lipids in water medium. Therefore, an effectively engineered delivery system of bioactive ingredients by SLNs and NLCs can be provided by the accurate and pre-designed formulation of lipids, emulsifiers, and water (Katouzian & Jafari, 2016; Wissing, Kayser, & Müller, 2004). In the following subsections, more details have been presented on these components.

sections.heading: 4.1. Lipids
sections.text:
The lipid matrix is a fundamental element in SLNs and NLCs so that bioactive ingredients could be incorporated in this matrix. Therefore, the appropriate selection of lipids is necessary for the entrapment of bioactive ingredients. There are some items that should be considered in regard to the lipids being utilized in the formulation of SLN and NLC structures, which include:
Good solubility of lipophilic ingredients within the lipid matrix High stability against decomposition factors, such as oxidation Being biodegradable, health-promoting and safe
A rational proportion between the solid and liquid lipids in the matrix (for NLCs).
The common solid lipids (rigid at the ambient and body temperature) used in SLNs and NLCs include glyceryl behenate (Compritol®888 ATO), glyceryl monostearate (monostearate), glyceryl palmitostearate plus stearic acid. Compritol®888 ATO is an amphiphilic material with a relatively high melting point (~70 C). The employment of Compritol®888 ATO in NLCs bring numerous benefits, such as enhanced encapsulation efficiency, increased physical stability plus the reduction in the rate of unwanted release, which can be attributed to the labile a-polymorphic form in the crystalline lattice (Souto, Mehnert, & Müller, 2006). Nonetheless, formulating NLCs with narrow size distribution is somehow complicated due to higher melting point and viscosity of Compritol®888 ATO. In contrast, the small and narrow-size-distributed NLCs can be obtained by compounds like monostearin. Monostearin is also used as an emulsifier, which is able to induce a controlled release behavior (Zhuang et al., 2010).
Glyceryl palmitostearate has a high melting point (52e55 C) and can be used to modify the release profile of solid networks in the oral cavity (lipid matrix for sustained release) (Deore, Kavitha, & Tamizhmani, 2010; Wen, Nokhodchi, & Rajabi-siahboomi, 2010). Also, NLCs can be formulated by some main solid lipids comprising fatty acids, such as stearic acid, cholesterol, and waxes (e.g. cetyl palmitate) (Fang, Al-Suwayeh,& Fang, 2013). Stearic acid,
also recognized as octadecanoic acid, is a biocompatible and foodgrade substance and is one of the most common long-chain fatty acids, found in animal tissues and vegetable fats. The melting point of stearic acid is 69.6 C and thus it is a good candidate for delivery purposes (Hu et al., 2005).
Liquid lipids (oils) are the key elements within the formulation of NLCs and mostly comprise digestible oils. There are two typical types of liquid lipids for the application in NLCs: saturated oils, such as medium chain triglycerides (MCTs), paraffin oil, isopropyl palmitate plus capric/caprylic triglyceride; and unsaturated oils like oleic acid, squalene, vegetable and seed oils (Fang et al., 2013; Müller et al., 2002a).
MCTs, such as Miglyol® 812, are most commonly used in NLCs as a liquid lipid. These oils have a similar structure with some common solid lipids like the glyceryl behenate (Compritol® 888 ATO) and can be easily combined with them in the inner phase of NLCs. The MCTs have a high stability against oxidation, however incorporating them in healthy formulations (like functional foods) can be problematic due to their saturation. Saturated oils can raise the blood cholesterol levels and lead to cardiovascular diseases. On the other hand, NLCs can be formulated by some healthy fatty acids, such as oleic acid and linoleic acid. These are usually obtained by the hydrolysis of various animal and vegetable lipids (e.g. olive) followed by separation of the liquid fatty acids. Oleic and linoleic acid are susceptible to oxidation more than triglycerides due to their unsaturated nature (DiNicolantonio, Lucan, & O’Keefe, 2016; Zhuang et al., 2010).
It is of utmost importance to prepare NLC structures by including novel, biocompatible and healthy oils in the formulations that are intended to be applied in the food and related industries. Some healthy bioactive ingredients, such as a-tocopherol (vitamin E) or other agents can be used as liquid lipids in the inner phase of NLCs. Tocopherols are functional elements and possess the advantages of being available, affordable, augmenting the solubility of lipophilic ingredients and to be applied in large-scale production processes (Tsai et al., 2012). The plants and seeds oil, such as soybean oil, olive oil, sunflower oil, sesame oil and cottonseed oil are also proper candidates for the production of NLCs (Joshi, Pathak, Sharma, & Patravale, 2008; Manea et al., 2014; Pardeike et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2008). Food manufacturers are eager to utilize plant and seed oils in the formulation of NLCs according to their cheapness, commercial availability, and bearing some healthy compounds like antioxidants.
4.2. Emulsifiers
Emulsifiers have a key role in the stabilization of lipid matrix systems. Most of the properties of SLNs and NLCs, such as particle size distribution, zeta-potential of the particle, encapsulation efficiency, optical and physical characteristics along with the stability of SLNs and NLCs are influenced by emulsifiers. As a result, picking a proper emulsifier is necessary for designing the intended type of SLNs and NLCs (Müller et al., 2002a,b).
Food-grade emulsifiers, which are employed in the food and pharmaceutical areas are classified into two main categories: macromolecular emulsifiers, also known as biopolymers (e.g., whey protein concentrate) and small molecule surfactants (e.g., Tween series). Currently, biopolymers have been utilized as typical emulsifiers for fabricating stable emulsions. Proteins (e.g., whey protein and casein) and polysaccharides (e.g., gums and pectin) are main biopolymers that can be used individually or in combination with the formulation of oil in water emulsions (Esfanjani, Jafari, Assadpoor, & Mohammadi, 2015; Mohammadi, Jafari, Esfanjani, & Akhavan, 2016b). Nevertheless, macromolecule biopolymers have not been wieldy introduced into NLC formulations, which can be
referred to their very slow rate of diffusivity and adsorbance onto the fresh interface in comparison to small surfactants (Jafari, He, & Bhandari, 2007). Consequently, the hydrophilic small molecule surfactants are normally implemented as emulsifying agents in the formulation of NLCs. Lipophilic surfactants, such as Span 80, Myverol® 18-04K, Span 20, Span 40, and Span 60 are also used to develop NLCs (Fang et al., 2013).
There are three broad classes of hydrophilic surfactants used in the formulation of SLNs and NLCs including (1) neutral, e.g., lecithin, (2) ionic, e.g., sodium cholate, sodium lauryl sulfate, sodium deoxycholate (SDC), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), sodium oleate and sodium taurodeoxycholate, and (3) non-ionic, e.g., poloxamer 188, poloxamer 407, Tween 20, Tween 40, Tween 80, Pluronic F127, Brij78, Tego care 450, and Solutol HS15 (Fang et al., 2013; Shah, Eldridge, Palombo, & Harding, 2015; Souto, Wissing, Barbosa, & Müller, 2004).
When the SLNs and NLCs are generated, the surface properties would change dramatically during the formation of nano-particles via solidification (cooling crystallization) of colloid nano-droplets. Thus, it is necessary to create a resistant membrane around the lipids with the help of surfactants. Lecithin is a major neutral surfactant that is abundantly used in SLN and NLC formulations. Yet, the formed bilayer membrane by only using lecithin could not reach the particle surface. Therefore, it is highly recommended to use a mixture of ionic and non-ionic surfactants with lecithin in order to obtain the best results.
The electrostatic repulsion potential among the surfactantcovered nanoparticles results in their elevated stability (Ninham, 1999). Generally, two layers (stern layer as an ion layer and diffuse layer as loosely associated ions) encompass the particles in solution commonly known as electrical double layer. Another factor influencing the stability of delivery systems is the zeta-potential, which is actually the electrostatic potential in the outer limit separating the stern layer and the diffuse layer (Mitri, Shegokar, Gohla, Anselmi, & Müller, 2011). Ionic surfactants are accommodated within the stern layer of the SLNs and NLCs and therefore the charge of SLNs and NLCs mainly emanates from the ionic properties of the surfactants. The highest zeta-potential can be achieved by using sufficient ionic surfactants within the stern layer. Thereupon, the ionic surfactant can increase the electrostatic repulsion potential energy among the particles and yield stable SLNs and NLCs. On the other hand, steric stabilization of SLNs and NLCs can be provided by the non-ionic surfactants. Small particles can also be provided by applying non-ionic surfactants due to the formation of a closely packed mixed film by intercalation of the non-ionic surfactant molecules between the phospholipids monolayer. In conclusion, by using a mixture of surfactants (ionic, non-ionic, and neutral), stable SLNs and NLCs could be obtained rather than stabilizing the intended system by employing only one surfactant (Han, Li, Yin, Liu, & Xu, 2008; Tan, Billa, Roberts, & Burley, 2010).

sections.heading: 5. Production techniques for SLNs and NLCs
sections.text:
Different techniques have been developed for the production of SLNs and NLCs with miscellaneous sizes and shapes. The size of particles scales directly with their functions but it is not the unique parameter considered to compare the various techniques. The production process is identical for both systems (SLNs and NLCs). Although there are several methods adopted in order to prepare SLNs and NLCs (Table 3), two processes of the high-pressure homogenization plus hot and cold methods are prevalently implemented to fabricate these delivery systems (Torchilin, 2006).
SLNs and NLCs are principally produced by two main methods: (i) the first method needs high energy, which is provided by high energy machines, such as high-pressure homogenization (hot and

Pre-mix using a stirrer to form a coarse pre-emulsion 4. High pressure homogenization at temperature above lipid melting point 5. Hot O/W nanoemulsion 6. 1. Melting the lipid and dissolving/dispersing of the bioactive in the lipid 2. Solidification of the bioactive loaded lipid in liquid nitrogen or dry ice 3. Grinding in a powder mill (50e100 mm) 4. Dispersing the powder in an aqueous surfactant dispersion medium (pre-mix) 5. High pressure homogenization at room temperature or below
(Mehnert & M€ader, 2001)
High pressure homogenization
1. The lipid is pushed with high pressure (100e2000 bars) through a very high shear stress 2. Disruption of particles down to the submicrometer or nanometer range
(Liedtke, Wissing, Müller, & M€ader, 2000)
Solvent emulsification eevaporation method 1. Lipids and bioactive compound are dissolved in a water immiscible organic solvent with low boiling point
2. The solution is then emulsified in the aqueous emulsifier solution. 3. Evaporation in a rotary evaporator at 50e60 C
(Wissing et al., 2004)
Solvent emulsificationdiffusion technique 1. Both the solvent and water are mutually saturated in order to ensure the initial thermodynamic equilibrium of both liquids.
2. Lipid and bioactive are dissolved in water saturated solvent and this organic phase is stirred using mechanical stirrer. 3. After the formulation of O/W emulsion, water in typical ratio from 1:5 to 1:10, is added to the system in order to allow solvent diffusion into the continuous phase, thus leading to the aggregation of the lipid in the nanoparticles.

Microemulsion technique 1. Lipids are melted and bioactive is incorporated in molten lipid. 2. A mixture of water, co-surfactant(s) and the surfactant is heated to the same temperature as the lipids

Solvent injection 1. Lipids are dissolved in a water-miscible solvent (e.g. acetone, isopropanol and methanol) or watermiscible solvent mixture

(ii) the second method namely low energy include using the controllable mixtures at low stirring (usually by using a magnetic stirrer) such as micro-emulsions, phase inversion temperature (PIT) and solvent based methods (solvent diffusion and solvent injection); besides NLCs can be produced by membrane contactors as a source of low energy (Weyhers, Mehnert, Hahn, & Müller, 1995; Müller et al., 2002a,b).

sections.heading: 5.1. High energy methods
sections.text:
One of the most commonmethods for producing SLNs and NLCs is high-pressure homogenization method (HPH). Concerning the temperature of HPH process, SLNs and NLCs can be prepared by hot or cold homogenization. The hot homogenization method is carried out at a temperature above the melting point of the utilized lipid. As mentioned earlier, NLCs are composed of an inner phase (liquid and solid lipid) together with an outer phase (emulsifier and water). In order to fabricate NLC structures via the hot
homogenization method, initially, the lipid matrix containing a mixture of solid and liquid lipid is mixed with the bioactive ingredient by a simple stirrer at a temperature above the melting point of lipid matrix. This combination is then dispersed in a hot surfactant solution at the same temperature to form a hot preemulsion by high-speed stirring. Subsequently, the final preemulsion is then fed to the high-pressure homogenizer. Finally, the NLCs are formed by cooling the hot O/W nano-emulsion in the ambient temperature, cold water or a heat exchanger to solidify the lipid droplet and precipitate the lipid nanoparticles, which leads to the formation of crystals (Müller et al., 2002b).
Sensitive ingredients cannot be encapsulated by hot homogenization method. In this manner, cold homogenization is an ideal alternative to the nanoencapsulation of heat-sensitive ingredients occurring at temperatures below the melting point of the lipid. Moreover, this method is best applied to hydrophilic bioactive ingredients. This practice has already been tested for SLNs, however its application in the preparation of NLCs has not been reported. In this method, bioactive ingredients are dispersed into a melt lipid
phase followed by quick cooling of the overall lipid mixture. After solidification, the bulk lipid is milled to produce lipid microparticles. The obtained lipid micro-particles are then scattered in a cold surfactant solution by simple stirring to yield a macrosuspension. Eventually, the micro-particles are degraded by the help of the high-pressure homogenizer apparatus and SLNs are achieved (Müller et al., 2002b). The cold homogenization of SLNs requires high energy input which in turn demands the harsh homogenization processing conditions. On the contrary, the fine monodispersed miniscule particles can be prepared by homogenizing molten lipids through hot homogenization method (Shah et al., 2015).
High-speed homogenization and ultrasonication: similar to high-pressure homogenization, this technique can be developed for the production of NLCs. In this method, the molten lipids are gradually added into the aqueous phase during blending via highspeed homogenization and subsequently, the NLCs are prepared by ultrasonication of produced coarse lipid particles from high-speed homogenization (Chen, Tsai, Huang, & Fang, 2010).
Another simple laboratory method for the fabrication of NLCs is called emulsification-evaporation, which involves an organic solvent together with high-speed/high-pressure homogenization or ultrasound technique. In this approach, the oil phase and bioactive ingredients are dissolved in a water-immiscible organic solvent (like chloroform and cyclohexane) to form a pre-emulsion. The resulted pre-emulsion is then emulsified in the aqueous phase containing hydrophilic surfactant via high-speed/high-pressure homogenization or ultrasound technique. Subsequently, the organic solvent of this solution is discarded by agitation at a certain temperature (emulsifying temperature) and definite time period (emulsifying time). Lastly, the prepared emulsion is cooled in the aqueous phase under mechanical agitation in order to fabricate NLCs (Wissing et al., 2004).

sections.heading: 5.2. Low energy methods
sections.text:
There is a thermodynamically stable method for the preparation of NLCs, so-called microemulsion in which these emulsions are spontaneously formed and no mechanical energy is required to initiate their formation. In this method, the lipids comprising a surfactant (and a co-surfactant, if needed) and the water phase are heated separately, mixed and subsequently titrated with the surfactant until a transparent micro-emulsion is observable. The hot micro-emulsion is then diluted with cold water (2e3 C) under stirring so that solid lipid and/or surfactant is obtained in the micelle (Chen et al., 2006).
Phase Inversion Temperature (PIT) technique is considered as a low energy method for producing nano-emulsions. Also, PIT has the potential for the production of NLCs. In this procedure, surfactant, lipids and water mixture are heated nearly above the phase inversion temperature and then the cooling process starts with continuous stirring. The mixture is treated with three temperature cycles, starting from the room temperature to PIT during magnetic stirring. In the last cycle, when the mixture is cooled, ice cold deionized water (0 C) is added to the combination. The rapid cooling-dilution action leads to the formation of NLCs (Heurtault, Saulnier, Pech, Proust, & Benoit, 2002).
Solvent diffusion and solvent injection are two typical solvent-based, low energy methods that can be used for the production of NLCs. Solvent diffusion includes the usage of partially water-soluble solvents (e.g., benzyl alcohol, butyl lactate, isobutyric acid and isovaleric acid). Concisely, the lipid phase (blend of liquid and solid lipid) together with the bioactive ingredient are dissolved in partially hydrophilic solvents. The final product is poured into the aqueous phase (water plus the surfactant) under stirring
(usually by magnetic stirrer). The obtained suspension is then cooled to the ambient temperature in order to form NLCs. Solvent injection approach is akin to solvent diffusion technique, with the exception that in solvent injection the solvent that scatters quickly in water (e.g., DMSO and ethanol) is used to dissolve lipids (Hejri et al., 2013; Hu et al., 2002, 2004).
Having discussed the beneficial application of these novel nanostructures, they also have their own deficiencies and limitations in their further implementation in the food sector. For instance, SLNs exhibit unpredictable gelation behavior and low space for the entrapment of bioactives owing to their dense crystalline architecture and propensity to polymorphic transitions resulting to the unwanted liberation of bioactive compounds (Aditya, Espinosa, & Norton, 2017; Gharibzahedi & Jafari, 2017). In addition to the advantages offered by NLCs, there may be some challenges in the employment of NLCs in the food area, such as the proper selection of food-grade ingredients, which can endure processing circumstances, crystallines may penetrate the liquid oil moiety in the system during collision and lead to the aggregation of particles termed “partial coalescence” causing instability. Ultimately, due to the increasing tendency of lowering the saturated fat crystals in food products, this solid portion of the NLCs must be chosen wisely to cover the human health concerns (Katouzian & Jafari, 2016; Puglia et al., 2017; Tamjidi et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 6. Bioavailability and potential toxicity of SLNs/NLCs
sections.text:
About a decade ago, there was a positive attitude toward the Nano definition. Nevertheless, the public viewpoint toward nanotechnology has changed due to the potential toxicity induced by some nanomaterials (Jafari & McClements, 2017; Katouzian & Jafari, 2016; Mokhtari, Jafari, & Assadpour, 2017).
Generally, there are three elemental routes by which consumers are exposed to the fabricated nanomaterials including oral, dermal and respiratory pathways (Jafari, 2017). Following the oral administration of nanofoods, due to their extraordinarily small size they are rapidly absorbed by enterocytes in the intestine (high rate of bioavailability) and enter the circulatory system (Fig. 4). Accordingly, they are carried throughout the body andmay be deposited in different organs or excreted from the body. Some strategies that are responsible for the higher rate of bioavailability when using SLNs and NLCs for transports of nutrients are indeed based on the conception of absorption process in the gastrointestinal tract. As illustrated in Fig. 4, these mechanisms are uptake by Peyer's patches, circulation of P-glycoprotein efflux from intestinal epithelium, and targeting of intestinal lymphoid tissue plus the development in digestive solubility (Jafari & McClements, 2017; Park, Garcia, Shin, & Kim, 2017; Yang, Liu, & Liu, 2017).
The long-term effects of consuming SLN and NLC structures are still an enigma and the studies determining their toxicological effects are in the infant stage. However, there are some works, which have discussed the effect of these nanocarriers inside the biological systems. As an example, Madureira et al. (2016) analyzed the imparted genotoxicity by SLNs (prepared by witepsol and carnauba waxes) bearing rosmarinic acid (RA) via in vivo tests. Lymphocytes were tested for possible DNA damage and apoptosis. Wistar rats were gavaged with free and encapsulated RA, subsequently samples were collected from their blood, urine and some tissues. In a nutshell, the levels below 1.5 mg/ml revealed no toxicity, however concentrations higher than that induced genotoxicity observed by the necrosis of Lymphocytes. In another study, Rahman et al. (2014) looked at toxicological effect of NLCs loaded with zerumbone (an anti-inflammatory phytochemical substance) following its oral administration to BALB/c mice. They isolated samples from the kidney, liver, spleen, heart, brain tissues and analyzed the serum
biochemical parameters to assess the possible toxicity of the administered nanostructures. To sum up, the oral levels of 100 and 200 mg/kg were considered safe in the tested animals and the lethal dose (LD50) of the utilized nanostructure was reported to be higher than 200 mg/kg and thus detected to be safe for consumption via the oral route.
As a final point, the structure of the utilized SLNs and NLCs must be studied in detail prior to their application in food systems since it influences the liberation and absorption of the payloads dramatically (Assadpour, Jafari, & Maghsoudlou, 2017; Mehrnia, Jafari, Makhmal-Zadeh, & Maghsoudlou, 2017; Mokhtari et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and future trends
sections.text:
SLNs and NLCs have opened new horizons in the field of nanoencapsulation of bioactive compounds in the food industry, with the ability to boost the encapsulation efficiency and bioavailability of the food bioactives. SLNs can incorporate complex bioactive molecules in themselves. As each entrappedmolecule has its own physicochemical and stability features, the preparation method should also be based on the encased nutrient to enhance the encapsulation efficiency as well as the stability of the core material; thus the environmental conditions plus the processing terms should be meticulously defined before the nanoencapsulation process. Furthermore, NLCs are capable of overcoming the disadvantages of other lipid-based nanovehicles; such as low bioactives loading, low encapsulation efficiency, and system instability. If the physical conditions of the entrapped lipid are controlled, burst release may be achieved, which is useful in the food sector, like flavor release due to heating in ready-meals. Both
NLC and SLN ingredients can be provided from low-cost, naturally occurring food components which can be employed as green formulations in the food and pharmaceutical industries. Meanwhile, there are also some challenges in utilizing these nanovesicles. For instance, the formulations need to be carefully designed since the ranges of approved emulsifiers used in the food products are narrow. Besides, the stability of nanocarriers should be tested as most food components undergo the conditions of pasteurization or sterilization during the processing. Ultimately, case-by-case toxicological assays and clinical trials must be carried out to assure that these novel nano-vehicles are safe for consumption.

referenceMentions.context: Today, the benefits of nanotechnology has influenced many branches in the food sector such as, packaging, bioactives compound delivery systems, and designing optimized formulations with the aim of increased bioavailability (Gibbs et al., 1999).

On the other hand, lipid-based nanoparticles bear the advantages of (Fathi et al., 2012; Mohammadi, Jafari, Esfanjani, & Akhavan, 2016a): biocompatibility more encapsulation efficiency targeted effect modified release low toxicity lack of organic solvent for the formulation ease of continuous production

Among the mentioned lipid nanoparticles, SLNs contain lipid droplets that are fully crystallized and have an organized crystalline structure with the bioactive components accommodated within the lipid matrix (Weiss et al., 2008).
Some of the advantages of the employment of SLNs as efficient nanovehicles are listed below (Madureira et al., 2015; Mozafari, 2006; Sagalowicz & Leser, 2010).

However, like other nanocarriers, SLNs also have their own disadvantages which are (Aditya & Ko, 2015; Weiss et al., 2008):
✓ The ingredients should not have a negative effect on the sensory properties of SLNs-incorporated foods (Du, 2011).

✓ Stability of SLNs must be examined during processing and storage of foods against mechanical and physicochemical stresses, such as pressure, stirring, thermal processing, light, drying, freezing, pH, and environmental storage conditions (Tamjidi et al., 2013).

NLCs, as one of the lipid-based encapsulation vehicles, can be successfully used as a fundamental delivery system for the fortification of foods accommodating a variety of bioavailable ingredients (Fathi et al., 2012).

There are two typical types of liquid lipids for the application in NLCs: saturated oils, such as medium chain triglycerides (MCTs), paraffin oil, isopropyl palmitate plus capric/caprylic triglyceride; and unsaturated oils like oleic acid, squalene, vegetable and seed oils (Fang et al., 2013; Müller et al., 2002a).
Oleic and linoleic acid are susceptible to oxidation more than triglycerides due to their unsaturated nature (DiNicolantonio, Lucan, & O’Keefe, 2016; Zhuang et al., 2010).

Tocopherols are functional elements and possess the advantages of being available, affordable, augmenting the solubility of lipophilic ingredients and to be applied in large-scale production processes (Tsai et al., 2012).

Generally, there are three elemental routes by which consumers are exposed to the fabricated nanomaterials including oral, dermal and respiratory pathways (Jafari, 2017).

As a final point, the structure of the utilized SLNs and NLCs must be studied in detail prior to their application in food systems since it influences the liberation and absorption of the payloads dramatically (Assadpour, Jafari, & Maghsoudlou, 2017; Mehrnia, Jafari, Makhmal-Zadeh, & Maghsoudlou, 2017; Mokhtari et al., 2017).

metadata.abstractText: Background: Lipid nanoparticles are innovative delivery systems, which are similar to the prevalently used emulsions, with the differences in size and structure in which the water-insoluble core is dispersed in a combination of solid and liquid lipids stabilized by surfactants. Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) plus nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) are novel and promising nano-vehicles, which are of great interest to be applied in the food sector owing to their exclusive properties, as investigated in this revision. Scope and approach: LNs and NLCs are produced to unite the advantages of structures like liposomes and emulsions and they can be formulated to achieve desirable protection and release of food bioactive ingredients. This review highlights the pros and cons of using SLNs and NLCs in the food industry. Furthermore, the commonly applied production methods and formulations along with the recently conducted studies in the field of food science and technology are underlined. Key findings and conclusions: These nano-vehicles have the potential to be employed in the food industrial applications in regard to their beneficial properties like simple production technology, low cost and scale up ability. These nanocarriers have been mostly applied in the pharmaceutical industries and are recently being utilized in the food sector, which seems to have great impacts on this industry as well as their commercialization in the near future. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd.
